thread.title: Donald Trump rips Turing CEO Shkreli as ‘spoiled brat’
thread.title_full: Donald Trump rips Turing CEO Shkreli as ‘spoiled brat’ - MarketWatch

author: Robert Schroeder
title: Donald Trump rips Turing CEO Shkreli as ‘spoiled brat’
text:
It’s Martin Shkreli’s turn to feel Donald Trump’s wrath.
“He looks like a spoiled brat to me,” Trump said about Turing Pharmaceuticals founder and CEO Shkreli, who made headlines for raising the costs of a drug from $13.50 a pill to $750 overnight. “He’s a hedge fund guy. I thought it was disgusting what he did,” Trump told reporters in South Carolina on Wednesday. The Hill has more on Shkreli, who has since said it “makes sense to lower the price in response to the anger that was felt by people.” The CEO didn't say what the new price would be, however. Hillary Clinton also called out the company.
Trump still on top after debate: Trump’s performance in the second GOP debate was widely seen as less than stellar. But it didn’t dent his standing in the latest Fox News poll. The billionaire gained a point, rising to 26% support among Republican primary voters, up from 25% in the Fox poll that followed the first debate . Marco Rubio got positive marks for his performance in the second debate, as did Carly Fiorina and Ben Carson. The new Fox poll showed Trump rated as the contest’s worst performer.
Pentagon employees did what? Did Pentagon workers try to get the government to pay them back for strip club and casino bills? The Pentagon’s inspector general is trying to find out , Reuters reports. In May, the Pentagon watchdog reported that Defense Department employees spent $952,258 at casinos and another $96,576 at “adult entertainment establishments” using official travel charge cards during a year-long period. The inspector general’s office said in a memo released Wednesday it is trying to determine whether the cardholders who used their travel cards for personal use sought or received reimbursement for the charges.
Democrats back bill to skirt shutdown: The House’s No. 2 Democrat says his fellow lawmakers will likely support a stopgap government funding bill that keeps current spending levels . Minority Whip Steny Hoyer of Maryland said Democrats would need to review the specifics of any measure passed by the Senate aimed at avoiding a government shutdown next week. Politico writes Hoyer said he expects House Democrats will join Republican leaders to pass legislation averting a shutdown. But aides say House Democrats will press Republicans to eliminate or reduce so-called sequester spending cuts in any long-term funding bill. The government is funded through Sept. 30.
White House says it didn’t block critic on Twitter: The White House said late Wednesday it isn’t blocking a 13-year-old conservative activist from following President Barack Obama’s Twitter account . Activist C.J. Pearson claimed the White House blocked him after he criticized Obama’s decision to invite Texas teenager Ahmed Mohamed to the White House. Mohamed was arrested for bringing a homemade clock to school that officials thought was a bomb. The Hill has more.
More from MarketWatch
